thread.title: Americans Scimeca and Knierim lead pairs at Skate America
thread.title_full: Americans Scimeca and Knierim lead pairs at Skate America

title: Americans Scimeca and Knierim lead pairs at Skate America
text:
(0) Comments 
Only once since 1991 has a pairs team from the United States topped the podium at Skate America. 
On Saturday, Alexa Scimeca and Chris Knierim have a chance to join John Baldwin and Rena Inoue (1996) as champions in the Grand Prix figure skating event that has been dominated by Russia, Germany and China. 
Scimeca and Knierim, the reigning U.S. champions, dazzled in the short program at the UW-Milwaukee Panther Arena on Friday. 
Skating to Metallica's "Nothing Else Matters," with their striking physical presence accentuated by black leather costumes, the 6-foot-2 Knierim and the 5-2 Scimeca struck just the right balance of grace and tension and sailed through the seven required elements in their 2 minute, 50 second program. 
They earned a score of 69.69 from the nine judges and took a 1.41-point lead over China's Wenjing Sui and Cong Han (68.28) into the 4-minute long program Saturday. 
"We are very proud of ourselves and happy with the way we skated," Scimeca said. "Since our last event at Nebelhorn (Trophy), we have taken this program and took the choreography and basically started from scratch and rebuilt the emotion and fire that needs to be brought when we skate it. 
"It's been a hard three weeks since Nebelhorn, because we've been working so hard in the mirror on expression and tension within the movements and it felt really great to bring it today. I think we made everybody in the audience feel something and that was the goal." 
Eight ladies competitors followed the pairs and all eyes were on 20-year-old Gracie Gold, who finished fourth at the 2014 Olympics and came into Skate America as one of the favorites. 
Gold, 20, skated well but made one costly mistake, turning her triple flip into a double. She received a score of 65.39 and was in second place, trailing 15-year-old Russian dynamo Evgenia Medvedeva (70.92) by a considerable margin going into the long program. 
"I'm really pleased with how I performed today but I'm also very, very frustrated," Gold said. "Things that I did in the program were so good, but you just can't mess up a jump in the short program. 
"It was really frustrating because I did the two (jumps) that were harder for me, which would be the triple-triple and my double axel. I conquered those and then just didn't hit the triple flip." 
Satoko Miyahara of Japan, the reigning world silver medalist, was in third place (65.12) and American Karen Chen was in fourth (62.28). 
Chen, 16, won bronze at the U.S. championships earlier this year. She was making her Grand Prix debut. 
"I'm very excited to be here," she said. "I remember as a little kid watching these competitions on TV. I'm very happy with how it went. I knew I could do a clean short program." 
The 4-9 Medvedeva also was making her senior Grand Prix debut after an undefeated 2014 season on the junior Grand Prix circuit. She's the latest in a long line of talented Russian skaters. 
"Every year there are new girls coming up and you have to be on top of your game if you want to be a competitor," she said through a translator. "If you work hard enough, things will fall into place." 
U.S. pairs Tarah Kayne and Daniel O'Shea and Jessica Pfund and Joshua Santillan, making their Grand Prix debuts, were in sixth and eighth place, respectively. 
Pfund and Santillan, who have been skating together for just six months, were last-minute replacements for Gretchen Donlan and Nathan Bartholomay. Donlan is recovering from symptoms related to an acute viral illness. 
"It's still kind of hard to grasp the concept that we are here at Skate America right now," Santillan said. "Once I got out on the ice I felt the energy of the crowd. There were a thousand thoughts going through my head, but we really tried to sell it out there." 
More than half the seats in the Panther Arena were empty in the afternoon session, but the crowd was enthusiastic. 
"I thought the crowd was amazing," Chen said. "They cheered from beginning to end." 
The Skate America competition concludes with two sessions Saturday. The pairs and ladies free skate starts at 1:20 p.m. and the free dance and men's free skate starts at 7:30 p.m. An exhibition, the Smucker's Skating Spectacular, is scheduled for 2 p.m. Sunday. Gary D'Amato covers golf and the Olympic Games and writes about a variety of other sports. He has won numerous writing awards from the Golf Writers Association of America, the Associated Press Sports Editors and the Milwaukee Press Club.
